column2: ON THE MOOR

column2: After tea my father went to his study, for it was late in the week, and he was a most conscientious writer of sermons.
column3: After tea my father went to his study, for it was late in the week, and he was a most conscientious writer of sermons.

column2: I read for an hour, and then, tired alike of my book and my own company, I strolled up and down the drive.

column2: This restlessness was one of my greatest troubles.

column2: At the end of the drive nearest the road, I met Alice, my youngest sister, walking briskly with a book under her arm, and a quiet smile upon her homely face.

column2: I leaned over the gate with my face turned towards the great indistinct front of Deville Court.

column2: Suddenly I heard an unexpected sound--the sound of voices close at hand.
column3: Suddenly I heard an unexpected sound-the sound of voices close at hand.

column2: A deep voice rang out upon the still, damp air--

column2: There must have been quite twenty of them, all of the same breed--beagles--and amongst them two people were walking, a man and a woman.
column3: There must have been quite twenty of them, all of the same breed-beagles-and amongst them two people were walking, a man and a woman.

column2: The man was nearest to me, and I could see him more distinctly.
column3: The man was nearest to me, and I could see him more distinctly.

column2: He was tall and very broad, with a ragged beard and long hair.
column3: He was tall and very broad, with a ragged beard and long hair.

column2: He wore no collar, and there was a great rent in his shabby shooting coat.
column3: He wore no collar, and there was a great rent in his shabby shooting coat.

column2: He was by no means an ordinary looking person, but he was certainly not prepossessing.
column3: He was by no means an ordinary looking person, but he was certainly not prepossessing.

column2: The sound of their voices came to me indistinctly; but I could hear the deep bass of the man as he slung some scornful exclamation out upon the moist air.
column3: The sound of their voices came to me indistinctly; but I could hear the deep bass of the man as he slung some scornful exclamation out upon the moist air.

column2: It was my first glimpse of Mr. Bruce Deville of Deville Court.

column2: I turned round with a terrified start.
column3: I turned round with a terrified start.

column2: Almost at my side some heavy body had fallen to the ground with a faint groan.

column3: I caught his hand and gazed into his face with horrified eyes.

column2: It was my father.
